data.title: Who is Usher? Everything to know about Super Bowl 58 halftime performer's songs, lyrics & more
data.meta_description: Usher is headlining this year's Super Bowl. That's sure to give the Las Vegas crowd a buzz.
data.text:
The hits keep on coming for the NFL, who have secured the services of eight-time Grammy winner Usher for its Super Bowl 58 halftime show.

Among the most prolific R&B artists of his time, Usher has enjoyed an eye-catching career currently stretching into its fourth decade. The 45-year old has soundtracked birthdays, weddings, funerals, and everything in between, becoming something of a symbol for R&B fans of a certain generation. His name still enraptures the masses, best evidenced by his recent live performance on NPR's Tiny Desk which has been viewed more than 20 million times.

Usher is one of the music industry's biggest names, but not everyone who is watching this year's Super Bowl is doing so for all the theatrics. Some rabid football fans are hoping to witness a classic display between the Chiefs and 49ers in the big game.

Perhaps you're not an Usher fan; perhaps you need a refresher on what he's contributed to the world of sound. After all, he hadn't dropped an album in nearly a decade prior to this year.

So, what is there to know about him? Have no fear, friend — The Sporting News has the answer, giving you the background on his career, songs, lyrics, and net worth.

MORE HALFTIME SHOW: All Super Bowl performances, 1-57 | 5 best | 5 worst

Who is Usher?

Usher Raymond IV, better known by his stage name, Usher, is one of the most successful R&B artists of his (or any) era. A Chattanooga, Tenn., native, Usher grew up in the church, honing his singing skills first as a member of a local youth choir, then, eventually, as a part of a secular music group.

Believing better musical opportunities were available away from his hometown, Usher and his family moved to Atlanta when he was a teenager. It was there that he found his sound, cultivating a rhythm all his own with Atlanta-based producer Jermaine Dupri. In 1994, he released his eponymous debut album, which peaked at No. 25 on the Billboard R&B/Hip Hop Charts.

It was his 1997 release, "My Way," that thrust him into superstardom. Spearheaded by "You Make Me Wanna" (which became the No. 1 song in the U.K.) and chart-topping "Nice & Slow," Usher cemented his status as one of R&B's most formidable acts. And he did all that at the tender age of 18.

Usher continued to exert himself all across the charts, spraying around No. 1 hits like seeds across dilapidated farmland. A singer, song writer, and dancer, he's the sort of multifaceted artist that has proven exceedingly rarer in today's musical environment.

Since the release of "My Way", Usher has put out six more solo albums: "8701" (2001), "Confessions" (2004), "Here I Stand" (2008), "Raymond vs. Raymond" (2010), "Looking 4 Myself" (2012), and "Hard II Love" (2016). On Thursday, he dropped his seventh individual solo release, entitled "Coming Home." The Super Bowl, then, offers the perfect environment to drum up interest in his latest project. What better space to entrench yourself than a glittering billboard of an event, perhaps the biggest in the American calendar?

Usher songs, lyrics

Usher has 53 songs as a lead or featured artist that have placed in the Billboard Top 100, not including charity or promotional singles. That includes 18 in the top 10 and nine that have topped the charts:

"Nice & Slow" (1998)

"U Remind Me" (2001)

"U Got It Bad" (2001)

"Burn" (2004)

"Yeah" (2004)

"My Boo" (2004)

"Confessions Part II" (2004)

"Love In This Club" (2008)

"OMG" (2010)

Another song, "Needed Me" (2016), was used in the Super Bowl 57 halftime show trailer. It peaked at No. 7 on the Billboard Top 100 and became the artist's longest-charting song at 16 weeks.

Below is a list of each of his chart-topping songs, as well as their accompanying lyrics.
